content.title: SUSTAINABLE BUILDINGS: EFFICIENCY, ELECTRIFICATION, AND EQUITY

content.text: ENHANCING RESILIENCE AND ADAPTABILITY OF ENERGY SYSTEMS

The buildings sector, which includes construction, heating, cooling, lighting, and appliances, accounts for over one-third of global energy consumption and emissions. Operations alone are responsible for 30% of global final energy use and 26% of energy-related emissions, with 8% from direct emissions and 18% from indirect emissions tied to electricity and heat production. While direct emissions slightly decreased to 3 Gt in 2022, indirect emissions rose to nearly 6.8 Gt due to increased reliance on electricity. Despite some progress, the sector remains off-track to meet the Net Zero Emissions by 2050 (NZE) Scenario. Addressing this requires a concerted effort to improve energy efficiency and adopt renewable energy technologies.

Despite some progress, significant opportunities remain untapped in the sector. Approximately 80% of economically viable energy efficiency measures have yet to be implemented. Building energy codes, which are essential for driving efficiency, exist in only 44 countries, leaving 82% of the global population in countries without such standards. This is especially concerning as global floor space is projected to grow by 20% from 2020 to 2030, primarily in developing economies. Additionally, decarbonizing the sector requires more than just new standards; retrofitting existing buildings remains a major challenge due to aging infrastructure (especially in advanced economies), poor insulation, and outdated design. Developing economies face the dual challenge of improving access to modern energy services, such as cooling, while simultaneously reducing emissions. Without immediate action, these regions risk becoming significant sources of energy demand and emissions growth. Policies, investments, and technologies must address this rapidly growing need while avoiding path dependencies that could hinder future decarbonization efforts.

Reducing direct or Scope 1 emissions (those directly produced by fuel combustion in buildings) requires improving energy efficiency and transitioning to renewable energy. The IEA estimates that 25% of emissions reductions needed by 2050 could come from energy efficiency improvements in heating, cooling, lighting, and ventilation. Renewable technologies, such as solar photovoltaics (PV) and solar thermal systems, could contribute an additional 30%. Governments are increasingly introducing measures to phase out fossil-fuel-based systems. This includes banning fossil-fueled heating appliances and limiting connections to gas grids for new buildings. Technologies such as heat pumps, which are rapidly gaining market share, are a cornerstone of this transition. Heat pumps are especially effective in well-insulated buildings, where their lower heating demand reduces costs and energy use.

Indirect or Scope 2 emissions (emissions from the generation of electricity, steam, heat, or cooling purchased and used by the building) stem from electricity and heat production. To tackle this, the sector must accelerate electrification while simultaneously decarbonizing the grid. Electrification enables buildings to transition away from fossil fuels while leveraging renewable-powered grids. However, ensuring the energy performance of building envelopes is essential to prevent undue strain on electricity systems during this transition.

Cooling demand is expected to rise significantly, growing from 20% of global electricity use today to 37% by 2050. The number of air conditioning units is projected to increase by 50% by 2030, further straining electricity grids. To address this, investments in grid resilience, advanced load management, and renewable integration will be essential. Heat pumps, alongside well-insulated buildings, can support this growing demand. These systems improve energy efficiency and reduce the peak load on electricity grids. However, managing cooling-related emissions will require careful planning to ensure grids remain sustainable and reliable.

· Integrate sustainable cooling targets within national and local policies, including the Nationally Determined Contributions, National Cooling Action Plans (NCAP) and city-level Heat Action Plans. Ensure that these integrated policies cover regulatory, policy, technical, and operational aspects to align with the Paris Agreement and Kigali Amendment targets under the Montreal Protocol. · Adopt a whole-systems approach to accelerate climate-friendly cooling. This entails developing frameworks that bring an “integrated cooling lens” while developing projects and programs across energy, buildings, transport, health and agriculture sectors. Policy options for accelerating climate-friendly cooling include: updating energy building codes and promoting green buildings with passive cooling measures, implementing fiscal incentives and improving operation activities. For example, Indonesia is implementing cool roofs, while Vietnam and Cambodia are promoting passive cooling solutions through building standards.

· Improve the energy efficiency of cooling technologies, including air conditioning and refrigeration. For instance, most air conditioners deployed globally have 2-3 times lower efficiencies than the highly efficient ones. Therefore, countries such as India, where the cooling demand is expected to grow 8 times by 2040, should focus on scaling the deployment of efficient technologies and enabling the development and innovation of new ones. Establish the Minimum Energy Performance System (MEPS), aligning with the global best practices. Singapore, for example, has adopted the Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) and Mandatory Energy Labelling Scheme (MELS) for ACs. · Leverage the digital era and innovation to improve energy efficiency. These innovations include smart cooling systems utilizing the Internet of Things (IoT) to optimize AC performance; and data analytics that enable predictive maintenance, reducing energy wastage.

· Use innovative business models to ensure inclusive and affordable access to cooling, especially in EMDEs. To reduce the burden of high upfront costs, countries should utilize business models such as pay-as-you-go, on-bill financing and cooling-as-a-service methods. After all, the question of cooling is one of equity. Over 1 billion people lack access to sustainable cooling, and a further 2.9 billion have ineﬃcient cooling, which disproportionately affects women and girls (SEforALL 2023).
Equity and Resilience in Building Decarbonization

Improving energy and building system resilience is vital for vulnerable populations living in poor-quality housing. These households face disproportionate risks from climate change, energy poverty, and associated health impacts. Ensuring equitable access to energy-efficient technologies can mitigate these risks while enhancing living standards.

Programs that lower borrowing costs for energy-efficient investments, such as government and utility initiatives, are essential. These efforts can support marginalized communities, enabling them to participate in the transition to sustainable energy while reducing energy poverty and associated vulnerabilities.
The Global Status Report for Buildings and Construction 2024-2025

A decade after the Paris Agreement, 2023 marked the first year in which building construction growth was decoupled from rising emissions. This shift was driven by mandatory energy codes, performance standards, and efficiency investments, reducing the sector’s energy intensity by nearly 10% and increasing renewables’ share in final energy demand by 5%. Further gains can be achieved through circular construction, green leases, retrofitting, and low-carbon materials, improving efficiency and reducing waste. However, the sector remains a major emitter, consuming 32% of global energy and producing 34% of CO₂ emissions, with materials like cement and steel contributing 18% to global emissions and generating substantial construction waste.

content.intro: Lesson 1 on THE IMPACT OF ENERGY SYSTEMS ON CLIMATE CHANGE

cards.title: Buildings Sector is a Major Contributor to Energy Consumption and Emissions.
cards.description: The buildings sector accounts for over one-third of global energy consumption and emissions, yet approximately 80% of cost-effective energy efficiency measures remain untapped. Electrification, particularly through heat pumps and renewable energy sources, is vital for reducing both direct and indirect emissions from buildings, emphasizing the need for immediate action.

cards.title: Urgent Action Needed to Prevent High-Carbon Infrastructure Lock-In.
cards.description: With global floor space expected to expand by 20% by 2030, especially in developing countries, there is an urgent need to implement building energy codes, promote efficient cooling solutions, and avoid high-carbon infrastructure lock-in. Failure to act now could lead to long-term consequences that hinder future decarbonization efforts.

cards.title: Targeted Policies are Essential for Addressing Energy Poverty.
cards.description: Vulnerable populations living in poor-quality housing are disproportionately affected by energy poverty and climate change impacts. To improve sustainability and living standards, targeted policies, innovative financing mechanisms, and government programs are necessary to ensure access to energy-efficient housing and technologies. This approach will help mitigate risks while enhancing overall resilience in the face of climate challenges.

lessons.title: Developing a Global Energy Efficiency Workforce in the Buildings Sector At COP28, countries pledged to double energy efficiency gains, requiring a skilled workforce. The buildings sector will create 1.3 million jobs by 2030, but labor shortages persist. This guide helps policymakers identify key energy efficiency jobs—insulation workers, energy auditors, HVAC/R mechanics, and glaziers—and align training with workforce needs through collaboration.

Global Monitoring of Policies for Decarbonising Buildings Buildings generate nearly 40% of global CO2 emissions. Without sustainable solutions, urban growth will worsen carbon lock-in. Energy-efficient buildings cut emissions, create jobs, reduce energy poverty, and improve health. Key challenges include renovating old buildings and ensuring policy alignment. Governments must incentivize action through grants and tax breaks, while new buildings should prioritize low-carbon materials.

Technology and Innovation Pathways for Zero-carbon-ready Buildings by 2030 This report provides the strategic vision of experts from the IEA Technology Collaboration Programmes (TCPs) on how to help achieve some of the most impactful short-term milestones for the buildings sector outlined in the IEA’s Net Zero by 2050 Roadmap.
